comment._content: A very powerfull picture of how things used to be.  I wonder what happened to all the skilled shipbuilders and their families?

comment._content: very nice image.

comment.author: 25453448@N02
comment._content: When I came to work in Newcastle-upon-Tyne in 1969, I saw the last days of scenes like this on Tyneside.  The local people said that when the ships were being built, they sheltered the streets from the wind, and they noticed the difference when the ships were launched and moved away.

comment.author: 69699465@N00
comment._content: Familiar scene to me too. I was at St Peter's primary school in Jarrow in the 60s, just down the road from Swans. Most kids' dads worked there and we got the day off to go and see launches.

comment.author: 23416270@N05
comment._content: This picture is absolutely amazing. And to see this in 1973, from this perspective, it must have felt like the end of the world. Machine over man.

comment.author: 41675580@N08
comment._content: Looking at this picture again, I still find it to be an awesome sight. The picture seems to encapsulate so much of a lost era of British maritime history.

comment.author: 78565921@N05
comment._content: Seeeing this picture, I would love to know what the street was (is) called. I would love to stand there and look with my own eyes. An amazing photo!

comment.author: 59478201@N04
comment._content: I saw this and many other ships being built between 1968 and 1973. I stayed at my nana's pub every weekend in Gainers Terrace, it was an awesome sight. At night the whole area was electric blue from the welders and it became very windy once the ships had been launched.

comment.author: 53218307@N06
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/59478201@N04]  The Ship Inn ?

comment.author: 59478201@N04
comment._content: Yes the Ship Inn and Its still there but looking very run down. If you stood in the same spot now you would be looking across the Roman Fort

comment.author: 59478201@N04
comment._content: I think this street would have been either Leslie Street or Davis Street, I was only a kid when I saw it so if anyone knows then do let me know.

comment.author: 16450152@N06
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/59478201@N04]  I think it is the end of Gerald street...used to live there in the mid 50's

comment._content: Skip to 9:20 to watch it launch from the same perspective: www.youtube.com/watch?v=Uqpr_00fsnQ

comment.author: 8964340@N05
comment._content: Great find kgunnar - thanks for posting.

comment.author: 41675580@N08
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/kgunnar] Thank you kgunnar, what a brilliant film of the times, I loved it!

comment.author: 69699465@N00
comment._content:
Thanks too for that link kgunnar. What an absolutely fabulous piece of filmmaking - no distracting music or commentary, just pure imagery and documentation of a powerful piece of British working life that's been blown away by global economics. 

I feel strangely privileged to have grown up right here and witnessed these events with my own eyes even if only as a kid. Although it's still a great nation, Britain truly feels like a poorer place without achievements like this to be proud of any more.

comment.author: 43171068@N07
comment._content: Anybody know if Roberts Terrace was nearby? My grandparents lived there until they died in the mid to late sixties. I remember seeing this view when I was 19
